title: Fire arm, taser, pepper spray used by police officers against animals
text:
Fire arm, taser, pepper spray used by police officers against animals BROOKE BATH Last updated 11:05, February 23 2017 BEVAN READ/FAIRFAX NZ 
Legal justification for police action against an animal was listed under either the Crimes Act, the Dog Control Act, the Animal Welfare Act and the Land Transport Act. 
Police use of weapons and force against animals is being questioned after revelations more than 1600 have been killed or injured by officers in the past six years. 
The animals had either a firearm, taser, pepper spray, baton or an empty hand used against them. 
They included a chicken, two ducks, five cats, 12 pigs and 24 goats according to information sourced from New Zealand Police under the Official Information Act. On average police are using force against an animal every two days of the year. READ MORE: * Family traumatised after police shoot treasured pet dog during search warrant in south Auckland SUPPLIED 
Lifeguards desperately try to chase away a shark which attacked and killed a swimmer at Muriwai Beach in 2013. 
While most police officers had no intention to be cruel to animals, said Hans Kriek, SAFE For Animals ambassador: "Every now and then you hear something and think, 'Really, was that the best decision?'" He said incidents such as ducks being shot seemed excessive. "We sometimes work with police and usually they're very good with animals. But there's always a possibility that maybe some officers don't care too much about an animal because it's seen as a danger to others or to itself," Kriek said. 
"We always urge for police to take the most humane action possible in the situation," he said. 
Dogs took the full brunt from officers with more than 1290 subject to force being used against them. And Kriek said it was justifiable to shoot at aggressive dogs who charge or put a stop to rampaging animals putting people's lives in danger. But even in those incidents, the decision to kill is not always clear cut. Auckland woman Uma Chand is angry her family dog Budz was killed by an officer in her backyard last year. Budz was a guard dog but was also considered a family member. He charged at a police officer who entered the back of the property during a search. LAWRENCE SMITH / FAIRFAX NZ 
Uma Chand and her family are devastated after police conducted a search warrant on their South Auckland house and shot their family dog when it became aggressive. 
The officer fired twice at Budz which killed him instantly. 
Chand said the dog was doing its job and police did not give the family a chance to call him off, without the need to shoot. 
"What hurts me the most is that my dog never had a chance against a bullet. In a split second he was taken... that officer's actions cost me a lot," Chand said. 
The figures also show police shot at, sprayed or hit 214 cattle, 64 sheep, 27 deer and 31 horses. 
Records of whether these animals were killed, wounded or simply hit were not provided by police. 
Nor would police confirm which of the incidents happened on public property or in private property. However, legal justification for police action against an animal was listed under either the Crimes Act, the Dog Control Act, the Animal Welfare Act and the Land Transport Act. The most common reason for using force was recorded under section 48 of the Crimes Act which is defence against assault, self-defence or defense of another. In December last year, a goat was tasered by an officer on a property in Oamaru after it was reported disrupting traffic on State Highway One. "Unfortunately it was pretty stressed out and quite unco-operative, so I tasered it," Oamaru Senior Constable Carl Pedersen said at the time. 
Two ducks, a chicken and a possum were all sick or inured animals that were shot under section 138 of the Animal Welfare Act. The same went for the five cats who were put down by officers after they had apparently been hit by vehicles. The most unusual animal shot at was a great white shark. 
In February 2013, Kumeu-based policeman Constable Rob Bailey shot at the shark after it attacked and killed swimmer Adam Strange at Muriwai Beach. 
The shark was not scared away by police circling it in a boat and would not release Strange's body from its jaws until it was shot.
